div.stage: Enter Elder Pallatine, and Thwack, dreſſing himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Quick, diſpatch Knight! thou art as tedious in
Thy dreſſing, as a Court Bribe; two ſhips might
Be rigg'd for the Straits, in leſſe ſpace than thou
Carienſt that ſame old Hulke, can it be thought
That one ſo fill'd with hope and wiſe deſignes
Could be ſubdu'd with ſleepe, what dull, and drowſie?
Keepe earlier howers than a rooſt Hen in Winter?

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Pallatine, the deſigne grow all Dreame, Magick,
And Alchymie to mee: I gave it loſt!
Clove to my ſoft Pillow, like a warme Iuſtice,
And ſlept there with leſſe noyſe than a dead Lawyer
In a Monument.

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.p: This is the houſe; diſpatch, that I may knock.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: S'light ſtay, thou think'ſt I've the dexterity
Of a Spaniell, that with a yawne, a ſcratch
On his left eare, and ſtretching his hind legs,
Is ready for all day: O for the Biſcayne ſleeve,
And Bulloigne hoſe, I wore when I was ſhrieve,
In Eighty Eight!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Faith thou art comely Knight!
And I already ſee the Towne Girles melt,
And thaw before thee.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Wee muſt be content!
Thou knowſt all men are bound to were their limbs
I'th ſame skin that Nature beſtowes upon them;
Be it rough or be it ſmooth; for my part,
If ſhe to whom you lead me now like not
The graine of mine, I will not flea my ſelfe,
T'humor the touch of her Ladi-ſhips fingers!

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.l: Well I had thought t'have carry'd it with Youth,
But when I came to greet her beauties with
The Eyes of Love and wonder, ſhee deſpis'd mee,
Rebuk'd thoſe haughty Squires, her Servants that
Convay'd mee thither in miſtake, and cry'd,
She meant the more Authentick Gentleman,
The rev'rend Mounſier, ſhee!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: The rev'rend Mounſier?
Why does ſhee take mee for a French Deane?

sp.speaker: Eld. Pal.
sp.l: Her Confeſſor at leaſt, her ſecrets are
Thine owne; but by what Charmes attain'd;
Let him determine that has read Agrippa.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Charms? yes Sir, if this be a Charm—or this— leaps and frisks.
Or here againe t'advance th'activity
Of a poore old back!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: No Ape, Sir Morglay,
After a yeeres obedience to the Whip,
Is better quallify'd!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Limber, and ſound Sir!
Beſides, I ſing, little Muſgrove; and then
For, the Chivie Chaſe, no Larke comes neere mee!
If ſhee be t'ane with theſe, why at her perill bee't!

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.p: Come Sir, diſpatch! Ile knock, for here's the houſe▪

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Stay, ſtay! this Lane (ſure) has no great renowne!
The houſe too, if the Moone reveal't aright,
May for it's ſmall Magnificence be left
(For ought we know) out of the Cittie Map!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Therein conſiſts the Miracle, and when
The doores ſhall ope, and thou behold, how leane
And ragged ev'ry roome appeares, till thou
Haſt reach'd the Sphaere, where ſhee (Illuſtrious) moves,
Thy wonder will be more perplex'd; for know
This Manſion is not hers, but a conceal'd
Retirement, which her wiſedome ſafely choſe
To hide her looſe love.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Give mee a Bagadg that has braines! but Pallatine,
Did not I at firſt perſwade thee, thoſe two
Trim Gentlemen, her Squires, might happily
Miſtake the perſon unto whom the meſſage was
Diſpos'd; and that my ſelfe was hee?

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.l: Thou didſt! and thou haſt got (Knight) by this hand
I thinke, the Mogul's Neece; ſhee cannot be
Of leſſe diſcent; the height and ſtrangeneſſe of
Her port, denote her forraigne, and of great blood!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: What ſhould the Mogul's Neece doe here?

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: 'Las thy Eares are buried in a Wool-ſack;
Thou hear'ſt no Newes! 'tis all the voyce in Court,
That ſhee is ſent hither in diſguiſe, to learne
To play on the Gitarh, and make Almond Butter!
But whether this great Lady that I bring
Thee too, be ſhee; is yet not quite confirm'd!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Thou talk'ſt o'th high, and ſtrange comportment that
Thou found'ſt her in!

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.l: Right Sir! ſhe ſat on a rich Perſian Quilt,
Thridding a Carckanet, of pure, round Pearle,
Bigger than Pidgeons Egges!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: Thoſe I will ſell!

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.l: Her Maids with little Rods of Roſe-marie,
And ſtalks of Lavander, were bruſhing Ermines skins;

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.p: Furres for the Winter! Ile line my Breeches with them!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Her young ſmooth Pages lay, round at her feet;
Cloath'd like the Sophies Sons; and all at Dice;
The Caſter ſix Wedges a Cubit long
Cries one; another comes a Tun of Piſtolets;
And then is cover'd with an Argoſie,
Laden with Indico, and Cutchy nill!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: This muſt be the great Mogul's Neece!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pal.
sp.l: As for her Groomes, they all were planted on
Their knees, carowſing their great Ladies health
In perfum'd Wines, and then ſtraight quallify'd
Their wild, voluptuous heats with coole Cerbet,
The Turkes owne Iulip?

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Knock, Pallatine!
Quick Rogue! I cannot hold; little thought I
The Thwack's of the North, ſhould inoculate
With the Mogul's of the South!— Pallatine knocks.

div.stage: Enter Snore.

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Speake ſoftly Maſter Conſtable, I've brought
The very hee Bawd!

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: Bleſſing on your heart Sir!
My Watch are above at Trea Trip, for a
Black Pudding, and a pound o' Suffolke Cheeſe;
They'l ha'done ſtraight: Pray fetch him to mee,
Ile call them downe, and lead him to a by-roome!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.p: Pallatine, what's he?

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: The Ladies ſteward ſir,
A ſage Phyloſopher, and a grave Pandar!
One that hath writ bawdy Sonnets in Hebrew,
And thoſe ſo well, that if the Rabbins were
Alive, 'tis thought hee would corrupt their Wives.
Follow mee Knight!—

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Halfe the large Treaſure that I get is yours!

sp.speaker: Eld: Pal.
sp.l: Good faith (my friend) when you are once poſſeſs'd
Of all, 'tis as your Conſcience will vouchſafe.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Do'ſt thou ſuſpect? Ile ſtay here till thou fetch
A Bible, and a Cuſhion, and ſweare kneeling!

sp.speaker: Eld: Pal.
sp.l: My Faith ſhall rather couzen mee; walke in
With this Phyloſopher — No words! for hee's
A Pythagorian and Profeſſes ſilence!
My Ring Maſter Conſtable— Snore gives him his Ring, then Exit with Thwack.
Here yet my Reputation's ſafe! ſhould hee
Have heard of my miſchance, and not accompany'd
With this defeat upon himſelfe, his Mirth
And Tyranny had beene 'bove humane Sufferance!
Now for the Lady Ample, ſhee (I gueſſe)
Lookes on mee with ſtrong fervent Eyes; ſhee's rich;
And could I worke her into profit, 'twould
Procure my Wit, immortall memory;
But to be gull'd? and by ſuch Trifles too;
Dull, humble Gentlemen that nere drunke Wine,
But on ſome Coronation day, when each
Conduit piſſes Cl • ret at the Towne charge!
Well, though tis worſe than Steele or Marble to
Digeſt; yet I have learn • d, one ſtop in a
But may procure him breath to win the race. Exit.

div.head: ACT. 4. SCEN. 1.
div.stage: Enter Yo: Pallatine, Engine, Meager, Pert, Pallatine richly cloath'd.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Your Brother's in the houſe; the Letter which
I ſent to tempt him hither wrought above
The reach of our deſires; My Lady Sir,
Hee does believe is ſicke to death; and all,
In languiſhment for his deare love.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: Pert, and Meager, though you have both good faces,
They muſt not be ſeene here; there is below,
A Brother o'mine; whom (I take it) you
Have us'd not overtenderlie.

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: S'light he muſt needs remember us!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Wee'l ſooner ſtay t'out-face a Baſiliske!
Whither ſhall wee goe?

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: To Snore the Conſtable: Morglay is ſtill
A Priſ'ner in his houſe; take order for's
Releaſe, as I projected, but (d'you heare)
Hee muſt not free him till I come.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Pall, will the dull Ruler of the night (Pall)
Obay thy Edict!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall:
sp.l: His wife will, and ſhe's his Conſtable!
Name mee but to her, and ſhee does homage!

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: Enough, wee will attend thee there!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: This way Gentlemen. Exeunt Engine, Pert, Meager.

div.stage: Enter Elder Pallatine.

sp.speaker: Eld: Pal.
sp.l: What's this, an apparition, a Ghoſt imbroider'd?
Sure he has got the Devill for his Taylor.

sp.speaker: Yo. Pall.
sp.p: Good morrow Brother, Morrow!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: You are in glory ſir, I like this flouriſhing!
The Lilly too, lookes handſome for a Month;
But you (I hope) will laſt out the whole yeare!

sp.speaker: Yo. Pall.
sp.l: What flouriſhing? O Sir, belike you meane
My Cloathes; th'are Ragges, courſe homely Ragges, beleev't;
Yet they will ſerve for'th Winter ſir, when I
Ride poſt in Suſſex wayes! —

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: This gayetie denotes
Some ſolitary treaſure in the Pocket,
And ſo you may become a lender too;
You know, I'm farre from home!

sp.speaker: Yo. Pall.
sp.p: I'le lend nothing, but good Counſell, and Witt?

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Why, ſure, you have no Factors ſir, in Delph,
Lyghorne, Aleppo, or'th Venetian Iles,
That by their Traffique can advance you thus;
Nor doe you trade i'th City by retaile
In our ſmall Wares: All that you get by Law,
Is but a dolefull Execution
After Arreſt; and for your power in Court;
I know your ſtockings being on, you are
Admitted in the Preſence.

sp.speaker: Yo. Pall.
sp.l: What does this inferre Brother?
Men of deſigne are chary of their Minutes,
Be quicke, and ſubtile!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: The Inf'rence is
You proſper by my documents; and what
You have atchiev'd muſt be, by your good Wits!

sp.speaker: Yo. Pall.
sp.l: If you had had a Sybill to your Nourſe,
You could not (Sir) have aym'd neerer the truth.
I ſaw your Eares and Baggs, were ſhut to all
Intents of bounty; therefore was inforc'd
Into this way; and 'twas at firſt ſomewhat
Againſt my Conſcience too!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: If not to vex
The zealous ſpirit in you, I would know why?

sp.speaker: Yo: Pal.
sp.l: Good faith I've ſearch'd Records, and cannot find
That Magna Charta does allow a Subject
To live by his Wits; there is no Statute for't!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.p: Your Common Lawyer was no Antiquary!

sp.speaker: Yo. Pal.
sp.l: And then (credit me Sir) the Canons of
The Church authorize no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.p: You have met with a dull Civillian too!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: Yet Brother, theſe impediments cannot
Choke up my way; I muſt ſtill on!

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.l: And you believe the Stories of young heires
Enforc'd to ſigne at Mid-night to appeaſe
The Sword Mans wrath, may be out-done by you!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.p: I were unkind elſe, to my owne good parts!

sp.speaker: Eld: Pal.
sp.l: And that your Wit has power to tempt from the
Severe, grave Bench, the Aldermen themſelves,
To rifle where you pleaſe, for Skarfes, Feathers,
And for Race Nags!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pal.
sp.p: It is believ'd Sir, in a trice!

sp.speaker: Eld: Pal.
sp.l: And that your wit can lead our rev'rend Matrons,
And tefty Widowes of fourſcore, to ſcale
(And in their ſmocks) for fraile commodities
To elevate your Punke?

sp.speaker: Yo: Pal.
sp.l: All this Sir, is ſo eaſie,
My Faith would ſwallow't, though t'had a ſore throat!

sp.speaker: Eld: Pal.
sp.l: Give mee thy hand! This day Ile cut off the entaile
Of all my Lands, and diſ-inherit thee!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.p: Will you Sir? I thanke yee!

sp.speaker: Eld: Pal.
sp.l: But marke mee Brother; for there's Iuſtice in't,
Admits of no reproofe; what ſhould you doe
With Land, that have a Portion in your braine,
Above all Legacies or heritage?

sp.speaker: Yo: Pal.
sp.p: I conceive you!

sp.speaker: Eld: Pal.
sp.l: O to live here, i'th faire Metropolis
Of our great Iſle, a free Inheritor
Of ev'ry modeſt, or voluptuous wiſh,
Thy young deſires can breath; and not oblieg'd
To'th Plough-mans toyles, or lazie Reapers ſwet;
To make the world thy Farme, and ev'ry Man
Leſſe witty than thy ſelfe, Tennant for life;
Theſe are the glories that proclaime a true
Phyloſophie, and Soule, in him that climbes
To reach them with neglect of Fame and Life!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pal.
sp.l: He carries it bravely! As he had felt
Nothing that fits his owne remorſe; but know,
Sir Eagle, th'higher that you flye, the leſſe
You will appeare to us, dim ſighted Fowle,
That flutter here below. Brother, farewell!
They ſay, the Lady of this houſe, groanes for
Your love, the tame ſick foole is rich; let not
Your pride beguile your profit! Exit.

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.l: I ſuſpect him! Not all the skill I have
In Reaſon, or in Nature can pronounce
Him free, from the defeat upon my Gold,
And Iewels! 'twas like a Brother! but for
His two Confederates; though I ſhould meet
Them in a Miſt, darker than Night, or Southerne Fens
Produce, my Eies would be ſo courteous ſure,
To let mee know them!

div.stage: Enter Ample, caried in as ſicke in a Couch, Luce, Engine, Ginet.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Roome! More ayre! if heav'nly Miniſters
Have leaſure to conſider or aſſiſt
The beſt of Ladies, let them ſhew it now!—

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: How doe you Madam? Oh, I ſhall loſe
The chiefe example of internall love
Of gentle grace, and feature, that the world
Did ever ſhew, to dignifie our Sex!

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Work on! I muſt ſtand Sentinell beneath! Exit.

sp.speaker: Eld: Pal.
sp.l: Is her diſeaſe growne up to ſuch extremitie?
Then it is time, I ſeeme to ſuffer too;
Or elſe my hopes will prove ſicker than ſhee!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: More cruell than the Panthar on his prey!
Why ſpeake you not? no comfort from your Lips;
You Sir that are the cauſe of this ſad hower!

sp.speaker: Gin.
sp.l: He ſtands as if his Legs had taken root;
A very Mandrake!

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.l: How comes it (Lady) all theſe Beauties that
But yeſterday did ſeeme to teach
The Spring to flouriſh and rejoyce, ſo ſoone
Are wither'd from our ſight.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: It is in vaine, t'inquire the reaſon of
That griefe, whoſe remedy is paſt; had you
But felt ſo much remorſe, or ſoftneſſe in
Your heart, as would have made you nobly juſt,
And pittifull; the Mourners of this day
Had wanted then, their Dead to weepe upon!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Am I the cauſe? forbid it gentle heaven!
The Virgins of our Land, when this is told,
Will raze the Monumentall building, where
My buried fleſh ſhall dwell, and throw my duſt
Before the ſportive windes, till I am blowne
About in parcels leſſe then Eie-ſight can
Diſcerne!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Shee liſtens to you ſir?

sp.speaker: Eld. Pal.
sp.l: If I am guilty of neglect;
Give me a taſte of dutie, name how farre
I ſhall ſubmit to love! the mind hath no
Diſeaſe above recovery, if wee
Have courage to remove diſpaire!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: O ſir, the pride and ſcornes, with which you firſt
Did entertaine my paſſions, and regard,
Have worne my eaſie heart away; my breaſt
Is emptier than mine Eies; that have diſtill'd
Their Balls to Funerall Dew! It is too late!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Ginet, my feares have in them too much Prophecie,
I told thee ſhee would nere recover!

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.l: For my poore part, I wiſh no eaſier Bed
At night, then the cold grave where ſhe muſt lie!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Luce, Luce! intreat the Gentleman to ſit!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Sit neere her ſir! You heare her voyce growes weake!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: That you may ſee your ſcornes could not perſwade
My love, to thoughts of danger or revenge;
The faint remainder of my breath, Ile waſte
In Legacies, and Sir to you, you ſhall
Have all, the Lawes will ſuffer me to give!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Who, I? ſweet Saint, take heed of your laſt deeds!
Your bounty carries cunning Murder in't;
I ſhall be kill'd with kindneſſe, and depart
Weeping, like a fond Infant, whom the Nurſe
Would ſooth, too early to his bed!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Nay Sir, no remedy, you muſt have all:
Though you procur'd her death; the world ſhall not
Report; ſhe dy'd beholding to you!

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.p: Goe to her Sir, ſhe'ld ſpeake with you agen!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: Sir, if mine Eies, in all their health and glory,
Had not the power to warme you into Love,
Where are my hopes, now they are dimme, and have
Almoſt forgot the benefit of light!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pal.
sp.l: Not love! Lady! Queene of my heart! what oathes
Or execrations can perſwade your faith
From ſuch a cruell jealouſie!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: I'd have ſome teſtimony Sir; if but
T'aſſure the world, my love, and bounty at
My death, were both conferr'd on one, that ſhew'd
So much requitall, as declares he was
Of Gentle humane race!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: What ſhall I doe?
Preſcribe mee dangers now, horrid as thoſe
Which Mid-night fires beget, in Citties overgrowne;
Or Winter ſtormes produce at Sea, and try
How far my love will make mee venture to
Augment th'eſteeme of yours!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: That triall of your love which I requeſt
Implies no danger Sir; 'tis not in mee
T'urge any thing, but what your owne deſires
Would chuſe!

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.l: Name it! like eager Maſtiffs, chain'd
From the encounter of their game, my hot
Fierce appetite diminiſheth my ſtrength!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: 'Tis onely this: for feare ſome other ſhould
Enjoy you when I'm cold, in my laſt ſleepe;
I would intreat you to ſit heare, grow ſick,
Languiſh, and dye with mee!

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.l: How! dye with you! Takes Luce aſide.
'Twere fit, you haſtned her to write downe all
Shee can beſtow, and in ſome forme of Law:
I feare, ſhee's mad! her ſences are ſo loſt,
Shee'l never find them to her uſe agen!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I pray Sir why?

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Did you not heare what a fantaſtick ſute
Shee makes, that I would ſit and dye with her?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Does this requeſt ſeeme ſtrange? you will doe little
For a Lady, that deny to bring her
Onward her laſt journey; or is't your thrift?
Alas you know, ſoules travell without charge!

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.p: Her little skull is tainted too!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.p: Is hee not willing Luce?

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: My beſt deare Lady, I am willing to
Reſigne my ſelfe to any thing but death!
Doe not ſuſpect my kindneſſe now; In troth
I've buſineſſe upon Earth will hold me here
At leaſt a ſcore or two of yeares; but when
That's done; I am content to follow you!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: If this perſwaſion cannot reach at your
Conſent; yet let mee witneſſe ſo much love
In you, as may enforce you languiſh, and
Decay, for my departure from your ſight.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Can you doe leſſe than languiſh for her death?
Sit downe here, and begin! true ſorrow Sir,
If you have any in your breſt will quickly
Bring you low enough!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Alas good Ladies! do you think my languiſhment
And griefe is to begin upon mee now?
Heaven knowes how I have pin'd, and groan'd, ſince firſt
Your letter gave mee knowledge of the cauſe!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: It is not ſeene Sir in your face!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: My face! I grant you; I bate inwardly!
I'm ſcorch'd, and dry'd, with ſighing to a Mummie:
My Heart, and Liver are not big enough
To choke a Daw! A Lamb layd on the Altar for
A ſacrifice hath much more entrailes in't!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Yet ſtill, your ſorrow alters not your face?

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Why no, I ſay! No man, that ever was
Of Natures making hath a face moulded
With leſſe helpe for hypocriſie than mine!

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.p: Great pitty Sir!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Though I endur'd the Diet and the Flux;
Lay ſeven dayes buried up to'th Lips like a
Deceas'd ſad Indian in warme ſand; whilſt his
Afflicted Female wipes his ſalt foame off
With her owne haire, feeds him with Buds of Guacum
For his ſalad; and Pulpe of Salſa for
His Bread; I ſay, all this endur'd, would not
Concerne my face! Nothing can decline that!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Yet you are us'd Sir, to bate inwardly!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.p: More than heires unlanded, or unjoynter'd Wives.

div.stage: Enter Engine.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: What ſhall wee doe? Sir Tirant Thrift's come home!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.p: Sir Tirant Thrift!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: My Ladies Guardian Sir!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: He meets th'expected hower, juſt to my wiſh!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: What, hath hee brought a husband for my Lady?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: There is a certaine one legg'd Gentleman,
Whoſe better halfe of limbs is wood; for whom
Kind Nature did provide no hands, to prevent
Stealing; and to augment his gracefulneſſe,
Hee's crooked as a Witches Bin!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Is he ſo much wood?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: So much, that if my Lady were in health,
And married to him, as her Guardian did
Propoſe, wee ſhould have an excellent generation
Of Bed-ſtaves.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: When does hee come?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: To night if his ſlow Litter will conſent;
For they convay him tenderly, leſt his
Sharpe bones ſhould grate together: Sir Pallatine,
I wiſh you could eſcape my Maſters ſight!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.p: Is hee comming hither?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Hee's at the doore! My Ladies ſickneſſe was
No ſooner told him, but hee ſtraight projects
To proffer her a Will of his owne making!
Hee meanes Sir to be heire of all: if hee
Should ſee you here, hee would ſuſpect my loyaltie,
And doubt you for ſome cunning Inſtrument,
That meanes to interrupt his covetous hopes!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.p: Then Ile be gon.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: No Sir, hee needs muſt meet you in
Your paſſage downe! beſides, it is not fit
For you, and your great hopes, with my dependancie
On both, to have you abſent when my Lady dyes;
I know you muſt have all: Sir I could wiſh
That wee might hide you here! —
Draw out the Cheſt within, that's big enough
To hold you: it were dangerous to have
My Ladies Guardian to find you Sir! — They draw in a Cheſt.

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: How! layd up like a bruſh'd Gowne, under lock
And key! By this good light, not I!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: O Sir, if but to ſave the honour of
Your Miſtris fame, what will hee thinke to ſee
So comely, and ſo ſtraight a Gentleman
Converſe here with a Lady in her Chamber!
And in a time that makes for hi • ſuſpition too,
When hee's from home!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: I hate encloſure, I;
It is the humor of a diſtreſs'd Rat!

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.l: It is retirement Sir, and you'l come forth
Agen, ſo ſage!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.p: Sir Pallatine! —

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Your Lady cals Sir, to her, and be kind!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Will you permit the laſt of all my howers
Should be defil'd with Infamie, proclaim'd
By lewder Tongues, to be unchaſte ev'n at
My death? what will my Guardian gueſſe to find
You here?

sp.speaker: Eld. Pal.
sp.l: No more, Ile in! but think on't gentle Lady!
Firſt to bate in wardly, and then to have
My outward perſon ſhut thus and inclos'd
From day light, and your company; I ſay
But thinke, if't be not worſe than death!— He enters the Cheſt.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Locke him up Luce, ſafe as thy Mayden-head! —

div.stage: Enter Sir Tirant Thrift.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Engine, where's my charge Engine, my deare charge?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Sick as I told you Sir, and loſt to all
The hope, that earthly med'cine can procure!
Her Phyſitions have taken their laſt fees,
And then went hence ſhaking their empty heads,
As they had left leſſe braine than hope!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Alas poore Charge! come, let me ſee her Engine!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: At diſtance Sir, I pray, for I have heard
Your breath is ſomewhat ſowre, with overfaſting Sir,
On Holy-day Eeves!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Ha! what is ſhee Engine?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: A pure, good ſoule, one that your Ward deſir'd
For love and kindreds ſake, t'have neere her at
Her death; ſhee'l outwatch a long Ruſh Candle,
And reades to her all night the Poſie of
Spirituall Flowers!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Does ſhe not gape for Legacies?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Fye no! there's a Cornelian Ring, perhaps
Shee aimes at, coſt Ten Groats; or a wrought Smock,
My Lady made now 'gainſt her wedding Sir;
Trifles which Maids deſire to weepe upon
With Fun'rall Tales, after a Midnight Poſſit.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Thou ſaydſt below, ſhee hath made mee her heire.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: Of all, ev'n to her Slippers and her Pins!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Luce, me thought Luce, I heard my Guardeans voyce!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: It ſeemes her ſenſes are growne warme agen;
Your preſence will recover her!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Will it recover her, then Ile be gon!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: No Sir, ſhee'l ſtraight grow cold agen! On! on!
She looks that you would ſpeake to her.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: Alas poor Charge! I little thought to ſee
This dolefull day.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Wee all are mortall Sir!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: I've taken care, and labour, to provide
A Husband for thee; hee's in's Litter now,
Haſtening to Towne; a fine young Gentleman!
Onely a little rumpled in the womb,
With fals his Mother tooke, after his making.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Death is my husband now! but yet I thanke
You for your tender paines, and wiſh you would
Continue it in quiet governing my Legacies,
When I am paſt the power to ſee it Sir;
You ſhall enjoy all!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: This will occaſion more Church building;
And raiſing of new Hoſpitals; there were
Enow before; but Charge you'l have it ſo.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Ile make Sir one requeſt; which I have hope,
You'l grant in thankfulneſſe to all my bounty!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: O deare Charge! any thing! Your Couzen here
Shall witneſſe the conſent and Act,

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Becauſe I would not have my vanities
Remaine, as fond examples to perſwade
An imitation in thoſe Ladies that
Succeed my youthfull Pride i'th Towne: my Plumes,
Fantaſtick Flowers, and Chaines: my haughty Rich
Embroideries: my gawdy Gownes, and wanton Iewels,
I have lock'd within a Cheſt!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: There Sir, there the Cheſt ſtands.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.p: And I deſire it may be buried with mee!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Engine, take care Engine, to ſee it done!

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Now Sir, I beſeech you leave mee: for 'twill
But make my death more ſorrowfull, thus to
Continue my converſe with one, I ſo
Much love, and muſt forſake at laſt.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Alack, alack! bury her to night Engine!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Not Sir, unleſſe ſhee dies. Her Anceſtors
Have ſojourn'd long here in St. Bartholmewes,
And there's a Vault i'th Pariſh Church, kept only
For her Family; ſhee muſt be buried there.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: I Engine, I, and let mee ſee; the Church
Thou knowſt, joynes to my houſe, a good prevention
From a large walke; 'twill ſave the charge of Torch-light.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: What Fun'rall Gheſts? the neighbours Sir, will looke
To be invited!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: No more than will ſuffiſe
To carry downe the Corps; and thou knowſt Engine,
Shee is no great weight.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: And what to entertaine them Sir?

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: A little Roſe-marie, which thou mayſt ſteale
From th'Temple Garden; and as many Comfits
As might ſerve to Chriſten a Watchmans Baſtard:
Twill be enough!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: This will not doe! Your Citizen
Is a moſt fierce devourer Sir of Plums!
Six will deſtroy as many as can make
A Banquet for an Armie!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: Ile have no more, Engine.
Ile have no more! nor (d'you heare) no Burnt wine;
I doe not like this drinking healths to 'th memory
O'th dead; it is prophane.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: You are obay'd!
But Sir, let mee adviſe you now to truſt
The care, and benefit of all your fate
Preſents you in this houſe, to my diſcretion;
And get you inſtantly to horſe agen.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Why Engine, ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: In briefe, you know, that all
The Writings which concerne your Wards eſtate,
Lye at her Lawyers, fifteene Miles from hence!
Your credit, hee not knowing (Sir) ſhee's ſick,
Will eas'ly tempt them to your owne Poſſeſſion:
Which, once injoy'd, y'are free from all litigious ſutes
His envie might incenſe her Kindred to!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Enough Engine, I am gone!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: If you ſhould meet the crooked Lover in
His Litter Sir (as 'tis in your owne rode)
You may perſwade him move like a Crab, backward;
For here's no mixture, but with wormes.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: 'Tis well thought on Engine! farewell Engine!
Be faithfull, and be rich! —

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: My breeding and
Good manners Sir, teach mee t'attend your bounty!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: But Engine, I could wiſh, ſhee would be ſure
To dye too night!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Alas good Soule! Ile vndertake
Shee ſhall doe any thing to pleaſe you Sir! Exit Thrift.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Engine, thou haſt wrought above the power
Of Accident, or Art!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: If you conſider't with a juſt
And lib'rall braine: firſt, to prevent
Th'acceſſe, and tedious viſits of the Fiend
His love-ſick Monſter; and then rid him hence,
Vpon a journey to preſerve this houſe
Empty, and free to celebrate the reſt
Of our deſignes!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: This Engine, is thy Holly-day!— Luce knocks at the Cheſt.
What hoa! Sir Pallatine, are you within?

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.p: Is Sir Tirant Thrift gone? open Lady! open!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: The Cazement Sir I will, a little to
Increaſe your witſhips allowance of aire!— opens a wicket at th'end of the Cheſt.
But th'troth, for liberty of limbs, you may
As ſoone expect it in a Gally Sir,
After ſix Murders and a Rape!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.p: How, Lady of the Lawne!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Sir Launcelot,
You may believ't, if your diſcreet faith pleaſe;
This Tenement is cheape; here you ſhall dwell,
Keepe home, and be no wanderer!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pal.
sp.l: The Pox take mee if I like this! ſure when
Th'advice of th'Ancients is but ask'd, they'l ſay
I am now worſe, than in the ſtate of a Bawd!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: D'you know this Lady Sir?

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.l: The Lady Ample!
Her vayle's off too! and in the luſty garb
Of health, and merriment! Now ſhall I grow
As modeſt as a ſnayle that in's affliction
Shrinks up himſelfe, and's hornes into his ſhell,
Aſham'd ſtill to be ſeene.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Couldſt thou believe,
Thou bearded Babe! thou dull ingenderer!
Male rather in the back, than in the braine,
That I could ſicken for thy love? for th'cold
Society of a thin Northerne Wit! — Eld: Pallatine ſings.

sp.speaker: Eld. Pal.
sp.l: Then Troyains waile with great remorſe,
The Greekes are lock'd i'th wooden horſe! Enter Yo: Pallatine.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Pall, come in Pall! tis done! the ſpacious Man
Of Land, is now contented with his owne length.

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.p: Your Brother's come to ſee you Sir!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pa.
sp.l: Brother! Mad Girles theſe I couldſt thou believ't ſirrah!
I am Coffin'd up like a Salmon Pye,
New ſent from Den'ſhire for a token! Come,
Breake up the Cheſt!

sp.speaker: Yo. Pall.
sp.p: Stay Brother! whoſe Cheſt is it?

sp.speaker: El. Pall.
sp.l: Thou'lt aske more queſtions then a Conſtable
In's ſleepe! prethee diſpatch!

sp.speaker: Yo. Pall.
sp.l: Brother, I can,
But marke the Malice and the envy of
〈◊〉 Nature: I am no ſooner exalted
To rich Poſſeſſions, and a glorious meen;
But ſtraight you tempt mee to a forfeiture
Of all; to commit Felony; breake open Cheſts!

sp.speaker: Eld Pall.
sp.p: O for Dame Patience! the Fooles Miſtreſſe!

sp.speaker: Yo. Pall.
sp.l: Brother, you have prayd well, heaven ſend her you!
You muſt forſake your owne faire fertile ſoyle,
To live here by your Wits!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: And dreame Sir of
Enjoying goodly Ladies ſix yards high!
With Sattin Traines behind them ten yards long!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Cloth'd all in Purple, and imbroadred with
Emboſſements wrought in Imag'ry, the works
O'th ancient Poets drawne into ſimilitude,
And cunning ſhape!

sp.speaker: Gin.
sp.p: And this attain'd Sir by your Wits!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: Nothing could pleaſe your haughty Pallat but
The Muskatelli, and Frantiniak Grape!
Your Turin and your Tuſcan Veale, with Red
Legg'd Partridge of the Genoa hils!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: With your broad Liver o'th Venecian Gooſe;
Fatned by a Iew; and your aged Carpe,
Bred i'th Geneva Lake!

sp.speaker: Ampl. Luce. Ginet.
sp.p: All this maintain'd Sir by your Wits!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: And then you talk'd Sir of your Snailes t'ane from
The dewy Marble Quarries of Carrara,
And ſows'd in Luca Oyle; with Creame of Zwitzerland,
And Genoa paſ •• .

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: Your Angelots of Brie!
Your M • rſolini, and Parmaſan of Lodi!
Your Malamucka Mellons, and Cicilian Dates!
And then to cloſe your proud voluptuous Maw,
Marmalad made, by the cleanely Nunnes of Lisbone!

sp.speaker: Ample. Luce. Ginet.
sp.p: And ſtill thus feaſted by your wits!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.p: Deafned with tyranny! is there no end!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: Yes Sir, an end of you; you ſhall be now
Convay'd into a cloſſe darke Vault; there keepe
My ſilent Grandſire company; and all
The Muſicke of your groanes, engroſſe to your owne eares!

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.p: How! buried, and alive?

sp.speaker: Yo. Pall.
sp.l: Brother! your hand!—
Farewell! I'm for the North! the fame of this
Your voluntary death, will there be thought
Pure courteſie to me; I meane to take
Poſſeſſion ſir, and patiently converſe
With all thoſe Hindes, thoſe Heards, and Flocks,
That you diſdain'd in fulneſſe of your Wit!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Helpe Pall to carry him! he takes it heavily! —

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: I'le not endur't! fire! murder! fire! treaſon!
Murder! treaſon! fire!—

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Alas you are not heard!
The houſe containes none but our ſelves! Ex. carying out the Cheſt.

div.stage: Enter Thwack, Pert, Meager.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: We bring you ſir, commends from Pallatine!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: I had as'live, y' had brought it from the Devill!
Together with his hornes boyld to a Ielly,
For a Cordiall againſt luſt!

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.l: We meane the younger Pallatine; one Sir,
That loves your perſon, and laments this chance,
Which his falſe brother hath expoſde you to!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: And as we told you ſir, by his command,
We have compounded with the Conſtable;
In whoſe darke houſe, y'are now a Priſoner!
But ſir, take't on my Faith; you muſt disburſe!
For Gold is a reſtorative, as well
To libertie as health!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: And you beleeve
(It ſeemes) that your ſmall-tinie Officer
Will take his Unction in the Palme as lovingly,
As your exalted Grandee, that awes all
With hideous voyce, and face!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Even ſo the Moderns render it!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: But Gentlemen, you aske a hundred pounds;
Tis all I've left!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Sir doe but thinke what a
Prodigious blemiſh it will be, both to
Your ingenuitie, and fame, to be
Betrayd by one, that is believ'd, no wittier than
Your ſelfe, and lye impriſon'd for a Bawd!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Sir name it not! You kill mee through the eare!
I'd rather Sir, y'ould take my Mother from
Her grave, and put her to doe Pennance in▪
Her winding ſheet: there is the Sum! —

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: I'le in Sir, and diſcharge you! Exit Meager.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Theſe carnall Mulcts and Tributes are deſign'd
Onely to ſuch vaine people as have Land;
Are you, and your friend Landed Sir?

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Such land as wee can ſhare Sir in the Map!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Lo'you there now! Theſe live by their Wits!
Why ſhould not I take the next Key I meet,
And open this great head; to try, if there
Be any braines left, but ſowre Curds, and Plum-broth!
Couzen'd in my Youth! couzen'd in my Age!
Sir, doe you judge, if I have cauſe to curſe
This falſe, inhumane Towne! when I was young,
I was arreſted for a ſtale commoditie
Of Nut-crackers, long Gigs, and Caſting Tops:
Now I am old, impriſon'd for a Bawd!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Theſe are ſad Tales!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: I will write downe to'th Country, to dehort
The Gentry from comming hither, Letters
Of ſtrange dire Newes; You ſhall diſperſe them Sir!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Moſt faithfully!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: That there are Lents, ſix yeares long proclam'd by th'State!
That our French and Deale Wines are poyſon'd ſo
With Brimſtone by the Hollander, that they
Will onely ſerve for Med'cine to recover
Children of the Itch; and there is not left
Sack enough, to mull for a Parſons cold!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: This needs muſt terrifie!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: That our Theaters are raz'd downe; and where
They ſtood, hoarſe Midnight Lectures preach'd by Wives
Of Comb-makers, and Mid-wives of Tower-Wharfe!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: 'Twill take impregnablie!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: And that a new Plantation Sir (marke me)
Is made i'th Coven Garden, from the Sutlerie
O'th German Campes, and the Suburbs of Paris,
Where ſuch a ſalt diſeaſe regnes as will make
Saſſafras dearer than Vnicornes Horne!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: This cannot chuſe but fright the Gentry hence;
And more impoveriſh the Towne, than a
Subverſion of their Faire of Bartholmew,
The abſence of the Termes, and Court!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: You ſhall (if my projections thrive) in leſſe
(Sir) than a yeare; ſtable your horſes in
The New Exchange, and graze them in the Old!—

div.stage: Enter Yo: Pallatine, Meager, Queaſie, Snore, Miſt: Snore.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Iog off! there's Pall, treating for your liberty!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: The Canopy, the Hangings, and the Bed,
Are worth more than your Rent! come, y'are overpaid!
Beſides, the Gentleman's betray'd! hee is no Bawd!

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: Truely, a very civill Gentleman!
'Las, hee hath onely roar'd, and ſworne, and curs'd
Since hee was t'ane: no bawdry Ile aſſure yee!

sp.speaker: Miſt: Snor.
sp.p: Goſſip Queaſie! what a good'yer would ye have?

sp.speaker: Quea.
sp.p: I am content, if you and I were friends!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: Come, come agree! 'tis I that ever bleed,
And ſuffer in your wars!

sp.speaker: Miſt. Snor.
sp.l: Sweet Maſter Pallatine, here me but ſpeake!
Have I not often ſaid, Why neighbour Queaſie,
Come to my houſe; beſides, your Daughter Mall,
You know, laſt Pompeon time, din'd with me thrice!
When my childs beſt yellow ſtockings were miſſing;
And a new Pewter Porenger mark'd with P. L.

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.p: I for Elizabeth Snore!

sp.speaker: Miſt: Snor.
sp.p: The Pewterer that mark'd it was my Uncle!

sp.speaker: Quea.
sp.p: Why, did my Daughter ſteale your goods?

sp.speaker: Miſt. Snor.
sp.l: You heare me ſay nothing! but there is
As bad as this (I warrant yee) learn't at
The Back-houſe! Ile have an Oven o'mine owne ſhortly!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: Come, no more words! there's to reconcile you
In Burnt wine, and Cake! Goe, get you all in!
I'm full of buſineſſe, and ſtrange Miſtery!

div.stage: Exeunt Snore, Miſt: Snore, Queaſie.

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.l: A hundred Pall! 'twas all his ſtore; it lies
Here my brave Boy, warme, and ſecure in Pouch!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Wee'l ſhare't anon.— What need your bluſh Sir Morglay,
Like a Mayd newly undone in a darke
Entrie? There are diſaſters ſure, as bad
As yours Recorded in the Citie Annals!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Your Brother is a Gentleman of a
Moſt even, and bleſſed compoſition, Sir;
His very blood is made of Holy-Water,
Leſſe ſalt, than Almond-milke!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: My ſilly reprehenſion's were diſpis'd;
Y'would be his Diſciple, and follow him,
In a new Path, unknowne to his owne feet.
Yet I've walk't in it ſince; and proſper'd as
You ſee, without or Land, or Tenement.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Tis poſſible to live b'our Wits! that is
As evident as light, no humane learning
Shall adviſe me from that Faith!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: Sir Knight, what will you give worthy my braine,
And mee; if after a concealement of
Your preſent ſhame, I can adviſe you, how,
T'achieve ſuch ſtore of wealth, and treaſure, as
Shall keepe you here, th'exemplar glory of
The Towne, a long whole yeare, without reliefe
Or charge, from your owne Rents. This (I take it)
Was the whole Pride, at which, ſome few dayes ſince,
Your fancie aym'd!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: This was Sir in the howres
Of haughtineſſe and hope! but now—

sp.speaker: Yo: Pal.
sp.l: Ile do't: whilſt my poore Brother too; low, and
Declin'd, ſhall ſee, and envie it.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Live in full port; obſerv'd, and wondred at?
Wine, ever flowing in large Saxon Romekins
About my board; with your ſoft ſarſnet ſmock
At night; and forreigne Muſick to entranſe?

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: All this, and more than thy invention can
Invite thee too.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Ile make thee heire of my
Eſtate! take my right hand, and your two friends
For witneſſes!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: Enough! heare mee with haſte!
The Lady Ample's dead!— Nay there are things
Have chanc'd ſince your concealment far more fit
For wonder Sir, than this: Out of a ſilly piety,
T'avoyd a thirſt of Gold, and gawdy Pride
I'th world; ſh'ath buried with her in a Cheſt,
Her Iewels, and her Clothes; beſides, as I'm
Enform'd by Luce (my wiſe Intelligence)
Five thouſand pounds in Gold; a Legacie,
Left by her Aunt more than her Guardian knew!

sp.speaker: Thwac.
sp.p: Well, what of this?

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: Your ſelfe, and I, joyn'd Sir in a moſt firme
And loyall League, may rob this Cheſt!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: Marrie, and will!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: Then when your promiſe is but ratify'd,
Take all the treaſure for your owne expence!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Come let us goe; My fingers burne till they
Are telling it! The night will grow upon's!
Onely you and I, I'le not truſt new Faces:
Diſmiſſe theſe Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.p: At the next ſtreet Sir!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: This is at leaſt a girne of Fortune, if
Not a faire ſmile. I'm ſtill for my old Problem;
Since the living rob mee, Ile rob the dead!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: On my delicious Pert! Now is the time
To make our Purſes ſwell, and Spirits climbe! Exeunt omnes.

div.head: ACT. 5. SCEN. 1.
div.stage: Enter Yo: Pallatine, Ample, Luce, Engine, with a Torch.

sp.speaker: Yo. Pall.
sp.l: Engine, draw out the Cheſt, and ope the Wicket!
Let us not hinder him the ayre, ſince tis
Become his food!

sp.speaker: Eld, Pall.
sp.p: Who's there? what are you? ſpeak!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: A brace of mourning Virgins Sir; that had
You dy'd in Love, and in your Wits, would now
Have brought Roſes, and Lillies, Buds of the Brier,
And Summer Pinks to ſtrew upon your Herſe!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.p: Then you reſolve mee dead!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: 'Twere good that you would ſo reſolve your ſelfe!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: She counſells you to wiſe and ſevere thoughts;
Why, you are no more mortify'd, then Men
That are about to dance the Morrice!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Ladies, and Brother too (whom I beginne
To worſhip now, for tenderneſſe of heart)
Can you believe, I am ſo leaden, ſtupid,
And ſo very a Fiſh, to thinke you dare
Thus murther me in bravery of Mirth,
You haue gone farre: part of my ſuff'rance I
Confeſſe a juſtice to me!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: O, doe you ſo!
Hath your heart, and braine mett upon that point;
And render'd you ſilly to your owne thoughts!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Somewhat miſtaken i'th projection of
My journey hither! Three houres in a Cheſt
Among the dead; will profit more than three
Yeares in a Study; 'Mongſt Fathers, Schoolemen,
And Phyloſophers!

sp.speaker: Yo. Pal.
sp.l: And y'are perſwaded now, that there is relatiue
To'th maintaining of a poore younger Brother,
Something beſide his Witts?

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo conceiv'd!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: And that we Ladies of the Towne, or Court,
Have not ſuch waxen hearts, that ev'ry beame
From a hott Lovers Eie, can melt them through
Our Breaſts?

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.p: Faith, 'tis imagin'd too!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: That though th'unruly Apetites of ſome
Perverted few, of our fraile Sex, have made
Them yield their honors to unlawfull love;
Yet there is no ſuch want of you Male-ſinners
As ſhould conſtraine them hyre you to't with Gold?

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Y'have taught me a new Muſick, I am all
Conſent, and concordance!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: And that, the nimble packing hand, the ſwift
Diſordred ſhuf • lle, or the ſlurr; or his
More baſe imployment, that with youth, and an
Eternall back, engenders for his bread;
Doe all belong to Men, that may be ſaid
To live ſir, by their Sinnes, not by their Witts!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Sir, whom I love not, nor deſire to love,
I am of your minde too!

sp.speaker: Yo, Pall.
sp.l: Madame, a faire converſion, 'tis now fit
I ſue unto you, for his libertie!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: Alas he hath ſo profited in this
Retirement, that I feare he will not willingly
Come out!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.p: O Lady, doubt it not! Open the Cheſt!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: A litle patience Sir! Enter Ginet.

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.l: Madam, we are undone, your Guardian is
At dore, knocking as if he meant to wake
All his dead Neighbours in the Church!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.p: So ſoone return'd! it is not midnight yet!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: I know the bayt that tempts him backe with ſuch
Strange haſt; and have according to your will
Provided (Madam) to betray his hopes!

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.p: Excellent Engine!

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.l: This Key convayes you through the Chancell to
The houſe Gall'ry! My way lies here; Ile let
Him in, and try how our deſigne will reliſh!— Exit Engine.

sp.speaker: Ample.
sp.l: Come ſir, it is decreed in our wiſe Counſell,
You muſt be layd ſome diſtance from this place!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.p: Pray ſave your labour (Madam) I'le come forth!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: No ſir, not yet!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pal.
sp.p: Brother, a caſt of your voyce!

sp.speaker: Yo. Pall.
sp.l: She hath the Key Brother! tis but an howers
Darke contemplation more!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.p: Madam, here me ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: Nay, no beginning of orations now;
This is a time of great diſpatch, and haſt;
We have more plots then a Generall in a ſiedge! — Ex. carrying out the Cheſt.

div.stage: Enter Thrift, Engine.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.l: None of the Writings Sir, and yet perplex
Your ſelfe, with ſo much ſpeed in a returne!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: The Lawyer was from home, but Engine, I
Had hope to have prevented by my haſt,
Though not her Fun'rall, yet the Fun'rall of
The Cheſt; Ah deare Engine, tell me but why
So much pure innocent Treaſure, ſhould be
Thus throwne into a darke forgetfulneſſe!

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.l: I thought, I had encountred his intents!
All Sir, that Law, allow'd her bounty to
Beſtow, is yours; but for the Cheſt; truſt me,
'Tis buried ſir; the Key is here ſir, of no uſe!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Hah, Engine! Give it me!—

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: And Sir, to vex your meditation more,
Though not with Manners, yet with truth; know there
Is hidden in that Cheſt, a plenteous heape
Of Gold; together with a Rope of moſt
Ineſtimable Pearle, left by her late
Dead Aunt by will, and kept from your diſcovery!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Is this true, Engine?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: That preciſe Chit Luce, her couzen Puritan
Was at th'interring of't; conceal'd it till
The Fun'rall formes were paſt; and then forſooth,
Shee boaſted that it was a pious Meanes,
To avoyd covetous deſires i'th world▪

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: Theſe Fun'rall tales (Engine) are ſad indeed;
Able to melt an Eye, though harder than
That heart, which did conſent to ſo much cruelty
Vpon the harmleſſe Treaſure!

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: I mourne within Sir too!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: Give mee the Key, that leads me from my houſe,
Vnto the Chauncell doore!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: Tis very late Sir, whither will you goe?

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Never too late too pray; My heart is heavie!

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: Where ſhall I wait you Sir?

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: At my low Gall'ry doore, I may chance ſtay long.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: This takes mee more than all the kindneſſe Fortune
Ever ſhew'd mee: a deſent tranſmutation.
I am no more your Steward, but your Spie! Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Yo: Pallatine, Pert, Meager, Snore, and Watchmen.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: There, there's more Mony for your Watch; me thinks
Th'ave not drunke Wine enough; they doe not chirpe!

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: Your Wine mates them, they underſtand it not.
But they have very good capacity in Ale;
Ale Sir, will heat 'um more than your Biefe Brewis!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.p: Well, let them have Ale then.

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: O Sir, 'twill make 'um ſing like the Silk-knitters
Of Cock-lane!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: Meager, goe you to Sir Tirant Thrifts houſe,
Luce, and the Lady are alone, they will
Have cauſe to uſe your diligence, make haſte!

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: Your dog, ty'd to a Bottle, ſhall not out-run me! Exit.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: Pert, ſtay you here with Maſter Conſtable;
And when occaſion cals, ſee that you draw
Your luſty Bill-men forth; bravley advanc'd
Vnder the Colours of Queene Ample, and
My ſelfe, her Generall!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: If Ale can fortifie, feare not! where's Sir Morglay?

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: I'm now, to meet him i'th Church-yard; th'old Blade
Sculks there like a tame filcher, as hee had
Nere ſtolne 'bove Egges from Market women;
Robb'd an Orchard, or a Cheeſe loft!

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.p: Wee'l wait your worſhip in this corner.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.p: No ſtirring, till I either come, or ſend.

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: Pray Sir let's not ſtay long, 'tis a cold night;
And I have nothing on my Bed at home,
But a thin Coverlet, and my wives Sey Petti-coat:
Shee'l nere ſleepe (poore ſoule) till I come home
To keepe here warme!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: You ſhall be ſent for ſtrait!
Be merry my dull Sons o'th Night, and Chirpe! Exit.

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: Come, neighbour Runlet! ſighing payes no Rent,
Though the Land-Lady be in love! Sing out —
sp.stage: They ſing a Catch in foure Parts.
sp.l: With Lanthorne on Stall; at Trea Trip wee play,

l.hi: For Ale, Cheeſe, and Pudding, till it be day:
And for our Break-fast (after long ſitting)
Wee ſteale a Street Pig, o'th Conſtables gitting.

div.stage: Enter Engine.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Sir, draw downe your Watch into the Church,
And let 'um lie hid cloſe by the Veſtrie dore!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Is hee there already?

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Fat Carriers Sir, make not more haſte to bed,
Nor leane Phyloſophers to riſe; I've ſo
Prepar'd things, that hee'l find himſelfe miſtaken!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Cloſe by the Veſtry dore!

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: Right ſir,
Ile to my Lady, and expect th'event of your ſurpriſe!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Follow Maſter Conſtable, one, and one:
All in a File! — Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Thrift, with a Candle.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.l: I cannot find where they have layd her Coffin!
But there's the Cheſt; Ile draw it out, that I
May have more roome, to ſearch, and rifle it!—
The weight ſeemes eaſie to me, though my ſtrength
Be old; how long, thou bright all powerfull minerall,
Might'ſt thou lie hid, ere the dull dead, that are
Entomb'd about thee here, could reach the Senſe,
To turne wiſe Thieves, and ſteale thee from oblivion!— opens it, and finds a Halter.
How! a Halter! what Fiend affronts mee with
This Emblem! Is this the Rope of Orient Pearle? —

div.stage: Enter Pert, Snore, Watchmen.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Now I have told you Maſter Conſtable,
The intire plot; marke but, how like that Cheſt,
Is to the other, where the Elder Pallatine
Lies a Perdu; Engine contriv'd them both!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Hah! what are theſe, the Conſtable and Watch?

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Ceaze on him for no leſſe than ſacriledge!

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Why neighbors, Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: Wee ſhall know now, who ſtole the Wanſcot Cover
From the Font, and the Vicar's Surpliſſe!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Alas grave Sir, become a forfeiture
To'th King, for Sacriledge!

sp.speaker: Thrif.
sp.p: Heare me but ſpeake!

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.p: No, not in a cauſe againſt the King!

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Lead to's owne houſe! he ſhall be Pris'ner there,
And lock'd up ſafe enough.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Vndone for ever!— Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Yo: Pallat: Thwack, with an Iron Crow, and dark Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Why this was ſuch a firke of Piety,
I nere heard of: Bury her Gold with her?
Tis ſtrange her old ſhooes were not interr'd too;
For feare the dayes of Edgar ſhould returne,
When they coyn'd Leather.

sp.speaker: Yo. Pal.
sp.p: Come Sir, lay down your Inſtrument!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Yo: Pal.
sp.l: I'm ſo taken with thy free jolly Nature,
I cannot for my heart proceed to more
Defeat upon thy liberty: all that
I told thee were ranke lyes!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.p: How! no treaſure trovar!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pal.
sp.l: Not ſo much as will pay for that ſmall Candle light
We waſte to find it out!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: I thanke you Sir! — Flings downe the Crow of Iron.

sp.speaker: Yo. Pal.
sp.l: You ſhall have cauſe, when you heare more; to this
Darke region Sir, ſolemne, and ſilent, as
Your thoughts muſt be, ere they are mortify'd.
Have I now brought you, to perceive what an
Immenſe large Aſſe (under your favour Knight)
You are to be ſeduc'd, to ſuch vaine ſtratagems
By that more profound Foppe, your friend, my Brother!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: How had I been ſerv'd, if I'ad brought my ſcales
Hither, to weigh this Gold? but on! your brother!
Whoſe name (let me tell you firſt) ſounds far worſe
To me then does a Sergeant to a young
Indebted Lover, that's arreſted in his Coach,
And with his Miſtris by him!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: You are believ'd: but will you now confirme
Me to your grace and love, if I ſhall make't
Appeare, that in a kind revenge of what
You ſuffred Sir, I've made this falſe, and great
Seducer of Mankind, to ſuffer more.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: The Legend, Talmud, nor the Alcharon,
Have not ſuch doubtfull tales as theſe; but make't
Appeare, I would have evidence!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pal.
sp.l: Then take't on my Religion Sir, he was
Layd up in durance for a Bawd before
He betrayd you to the ſame preferment!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Shall this be juſtify'd, when my diſgrace
Comes to be knowne; wilt thou then witneſſe it?

sp.speaker: Yo: Pal.
sp.l: With a deepe oath! And Sir, to tempt more of
Your favours on poore mee, that ever mourn'd
For all your ſufferings; know you ſhall now
See him inclos'd in a blind Cheſt; where hee
Lies bath'd Sir, in a greater ſwet than ere
Cornelius tooke in his owne Tub!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Here amongſt Sepulchers, and mallencholy bones:
Let mee but ſee't; and I will dye for joy,
To make thee inſtantly my heire!

sp.speaker: Yo. Pal.
sp.l: You ſhall; and yet ere the Sun riſe, find him
Enthrall'd too in a new diſtreſſe!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Do'ſt want money? bring mee to Parchment and
A Scriv'ner, Ile ſeale out two pound of Wax.— Yo. Pall: knocks at the Cheſt.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pal.
sp.p: You Sir, my neer'ſt Ally, are you aſleep?

sp.speaker: Eld: Pal.
sp.p: O Brother, art thou come! quick, let me forth.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pal.
sp.l: Here is a certaine friend of yours preſents
His loving viſit Sir!— Opens the Wicket.

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Sir Morglay Thwack?
I had rather have ſeene my ſiſter naked!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: What, like a baſhfull Badger doe you draw
Your head into your hole agen? Come ſir,
Out with that ſage Noddle, that has contriv'd
So cunningly for me, and your deare ſelfe!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Here, take my Eielids Knight, and ſow'em up,
I dare not ſee thy face!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: But what thinke you
Of a new Iourney from the North, to live
Here by your Wits; or midnight viſits ſir,
To the Mogols Neece!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: I have offended Knight!
Whip me with wire, headed with Rowels of
Sharpe Ripon Spurs! Ile endure any thing
Rather than thee!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Wee have (I thanke your bounteous braine)
Beene entertain'd with various conſorts ſir,
Of whiſpring Lutes, to ſooth us into ſlumbers,
Spirits of Clare to bathe our Temples in,
And then the wholſome wombe of woman too,
That never teem'd, all this for nothing ſir!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.p: Come, Ile let him forth!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Rogue! if thou lov'ſt me!
Nay, let him be confin'd thus, one ſhort moneth!
Ile ſend him downe to Countrey Faires for a
New motion made, b'a Germane Ingener!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.p: 'Las, he is my Brother.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Or for a ſolitary Ape,
Lead captive thus by th' Hollander, becauſe
He came aloft for Spaine, and would not for the States!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: Sir Morglay leave your Lanthorne here, and ſtay
My comming at yon dore; Ile let him out!
But for the new diſtreſſe, I promis'd on
His perſon, take it on my manhood ſir,
He feeles it ſtrait!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.p: Finely enſnar'd agen, and inſtantly!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.p: Have a good faith, and goe! Exit Thwack.

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.p: Deare Brother, wilt thou give me liberty!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: Vpon condition ſir, you kiſſe theſe Hilts,
Sweare not to follow me, but here remaine
Vntill the Lady Ample ſhall conſent,
To'th freedome I beſtow!— He kiſſes the Hilts.

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.p: Tis done! a vow inviolate! He opens the Cheſt and lets him out.

sp.speaker: Yo. Pall.
sp.l: Now ſilence Brother! not one curſe, nor thankes—

div.stage: Exit Yo▪ Pall.

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: Fate, and a good Starr ſpeed me! though I have
Long ſince amaz'd my ſelfe e'ne to a Marble,
Yet I have courage left, to aske, what this
Might meane? Was ever Two legg'd Man thus uſ'd!—

div.stage: Enter Pert, Snore, & Watchmen.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Pall, and his friend are gone, I muſt not ſtay
His ſight; but after you have ceaz'd upon him
Lead him a Priſoner to the Lady too. — Exit Pert.

sp.speaker: Sno.
sp.p: Warrant ye, though he were Gog, or Heldebrand!— they lay hold on him.

sp.speaker: Eld. Pal:
sp.p: How now? What meane you Sirs?

sp.speaker: Snore.
sp.p: Yield to the Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Eld. Pal.
sp.l: 'Tis yielded ſir, that you are Conſtable!
But where have I offended!

sp.speaker: Snore.
sp.l: Heere Sir, you have committed Sacriledge,
And robb'd an Aldermans Tombe, of himſelfe,
And his Two Sonnes kneeling in Braſſe!

sp.speaker: Eld. Pal.
sp.p: How, Flea Monuments of their Brazen skinnes?

sp.speaker: Snore.
sp.l: Looke, a Darke Lanthorne, and an Iron Crow!
Fine evidence for a Iurie!—

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.l: I like this plott! The Lady Ample and
My Brother, have moſt rare, triumphant Witts;
Now by this hand, I am moſt eagerly
In love with both; I finde I have deſerv'd all;
And am reſolv'd t'hugge them, and their deſignes;
Though they afflict me more, and more! Whither muſt I goe?

sp.speaker: Snore.
sp.l: Away with him! Saucie fellow! examine
The Kings Conſtable▪ — Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Young Pallatine, Thwack, Ample, Luce, Meager.

sp.speaker: Meager.
sp.l: I am become your Guardians Iaylor, Lady;
Hee's ſafe lock'd in the Parlor, and there howles
Like a Dogg that ſees a Witch flying!

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: I long to heare how my wiſe Tutor thrives
I'th new defeat!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: 'Tis well you are converted!
Beleev't that Gentleman deſerves your thankes.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Lady ſeale my converſion on you Lipp;
'Tis the firſt leading Kiſſe, that I intend
For after chaſtetie!— kiſſes her.

sp.speaker: Yo. Pal.
sp.l: Luce, ſee you make the propoſition good
Which I ſhall give my Brother from this Lady,
Or Ile ſo ſwaddle your ſmall Bones.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Sweet Pall, thou ſhalt. Madam, you'l pleaſe to ſtand
To what I lately mention'd to your owne deſire?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: To ev'ry particle, and more. — Enter Pert.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Your Brother's come; this roome muſt be his priſon.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: 'Way Luce, away: ſtand in the Cloſet Madam,
That you may heare us both, and reach my call.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.p: Ile ſtay, and ſee him.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: No Knight; you are decreed Sir Tirants Iudge:
Goe that way Sir, and force him to compound.

sp.speaker: Thwack.
sp.l: Ile fine him ſoundly,
Till's Purſe ſhrink like a Bladder in the fire▪— Ex. Amp. Luc. Thw. Meag. Pert.

div.stage: Enter Snore, Elder Pallatine.

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: Here Sir, this is your Iayle, too good for ſuch
A great Offender.

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.l: Sacriledge! very well.
Now all the Pulpit Cuſhions, all the Hearſe Clothes,
And winding ſheets, that have been ſtolne about
The Towne this yeare, will be laid to my charge!

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: Pray leave us Maſter Conſtable, and looke
Vnto your other Bondman in the Parler. — Exit Snore.

sp.speaker: Eld: Pal.
sp.l: This is the wittieſt off-ſpring that our name
Ere had: I love him beyond hope, or luſt,
My Father was no Poet ſure, I wonder
How hee got him?

sp.speaker: Yo. Pal.
sp.p: I know you curſe me now.

sp.speaker: Eld. Pal.
sp.p: Brother, introth you lie, and who ere believes it.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pal.
sp.l: Indeed you doe: Conjurers in a Circle,
That have rais'd up a wrong ſpirit, curſe not
So much, nor yet ſo inwardly.

sp.speaker: Eld: Pal.
sp.p: I've a great mind to kiſſe thee.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pal.
sp.p: You have not ſure?

sp.speaker: Eld: Pal.
sp.l: I ſhall do't, and eate up thy lips ſo far,
Till th'aſt nothing left to cover thy teeth.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pal.
sp.l: And can you thinke all the afflictions you
Endur'd, were merited; firſt, for miſleading
Morglay, your old friend; then, neglect of mee,
And haughty over-vallewing your ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Eld: Pal.
sp.l: Brother, I murmur not; the Traps that you
Have layd, were ſo ingenious, I could wiſh
To fall in them agen.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pal.
sp.l: The Lady Ample Sir,
There is the great contriver that hath weav'd
Theſe knots ſo intricate and ſafe: 'Las, I
Was but her lowly Inſtrument.

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.l: Ah that Lady! were I a King, ſhee ſhould
Sit with me under my beſt Canopie,
A ſilver Scepter in her hand; with which,
I'd give her leave to breake my head for ev'ry fault
I did commit.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: But ſay, I bring this Lady Sir, unto
Your lawfull ſheets; make her your boſome wife:
Beſides, the plenty of her heritage,
How would it ſound, that you had conquer'd her
Who hath ſo often conquer'd you?

sp.speaker: Eld. Pall.
sp.p: Deare Brother, no new plots.

sp.speaker: Yo. Pall.
sp.l: Six thouſand pounds Sir is your yearly Rent;
A faire temptation to a diſcreet Lady:
Luce, hath fill'd both mine Eares with hope; beſides,
I heard her ſay, ſhee nere ſhould meet a man,
That ſhe could more ſubdue with Wit, and Government.

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.p: That Ile venture.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pal.
sp.l: Well, my firſt bounty is your freedome Sir;
For'th Conſtable obayes no Law, but mine.
And now, Madam! Appeare! — Enter Ample, Luce.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Y'are welcome 'mongſt the living Sir?

sp.speaker: Eld, Pal.
sp.l: Lady, no words; if y'have but ſo much Mercie
As could ſecure one that your Eies affect.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Why, you'r growne arrogant agen: d'you thinke
They are ſo weake, to affect you?

sp.speaker: Eld. Pal.
sp.l: I have a heart ſo kind unto my ſelfe,
To wiſh they could; O we ſhould live.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Not by our Wits.

sp.speaker: Eld: Pal.
sp.l: No, no! but with ſuch ſoft content; ſtill in
Conſpiracie, how to betray our ſelves
To new delights, keepe harmonie, with no
More noyſe, than what the upper motions make;
And this ſo conſtant too, Turtles themſelves,
Seeing our faith, ſhall ſlight their owne, and pine
With jealouſie.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Luce, the youth talkes ſence now, no Med'cine for
The braine, like to captivity in a darke Cheſt.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.p: O Madam, you are cruell!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Well my ſad Convertite: joy yet at this:
I've often made a vow, to marry on
That very day my Wardſhip is expir'd:
And two howres ſince, that liberty begun.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Nay, heare her out! your wiſhes are ſo ſawcie Sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: And know, my glory is diſpatch. My Anceſtors
Were of the fierie French, and taught me love,
Hot eagerneſſe, and haſte!

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.l: Let mee be rude
A while; lye with your judgement, and beget
Sages on that! My deareſt, chiefeſt Lady!—

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Your braine's yet fowle, and will recoyle agen.

sp.speaker: Eld▪ Pall.
sp.p: No more: Ile ſwallow downe my Tongue!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: If Sir, your nature be ſo excellent,
As your kind Brother hath confirm'd to Luce.
And mee; follow, and Ile preſent you ſtraight
With certaine writings you ſhall ſeale to, hood-winck'd,
And purely ignorant of what they are?
This is the ſwifteſt, and the eaſieſt teſt,
That I can make of your bold love; doe this,
Perhaps, I may vouchſafe to marrie you▪
The writings are within.

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.p: Lead mee to triall, come!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: But Sir, if I ſhould marry you; it is
In confidence, I have the better Wit;
And can ſubdue you ſtill to quietneſſe,
Meeke ſufferings, and patient awe.

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.p: You rap me ſtill anew.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.p: In Luce, our hopes grow ſtrong, and Giantly! Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Thrift, Snore, Miſt: Snore, Queaſie, Ginet.

sp.speaker: Ginet.
sp.l: To him Miſtriſſe Snore; 'tis hee has kept
Your Husband from his Bed ſo long, to watch
Him for a Church Robberie!

sp.speaker: Miſt: Snor.
sp.l: Ah, thou Iudas! I thought what thou'ldſt come to!
Remember the Warrant thou ſent'ſt for mee
Into Duck-lane, 'cauſe I call'd thy Mayd Trot!
When I was faine t'invite thy Clerke to a
Fee Pye, ſent me b'a Temple Cooke, my Siſters Sweet-heart!

sp.speaker: Quea.
sp.l: Nay, and remember who was brought to bed
Under thy Coach houſe wall; when thou deuid'ſt
A wad of ſtraw, and wouldſt not joyne thy halfe-penny
To ſend for Milke, for the poore Chriſome!

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: Now you may ſweeten me with Sugar-loaves
At New-yeares-tide, as I have you Sir. —

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Wee'l teach you to rob Churches! S'light, hereafter
Wee of the Pious ſhall be afrayd to goe
To a long Exerciſe, for feare our Pockets ſhould
Be pick'd! Come Sir, you ſee already how
The neighbours throng to find you; will you conſent?
Tis but a thouſand pounds a piece to theſe
Two Gentlemen; and five hundred more t' Engine.
Your crime is then conceal'd, and your ſelfe free.

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: No, he may chuſe, hee'l truſt to'th kind hearted Law.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Let him, and to Dame Iuſtice too, who though
Her Ladiſhip be blind, will grope hard Sir,
To find your Money Bags.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.l: Sir you are rich▪ beſides, you know what you
Have got by your Wards death; I feare you will
Be begg'd at Court, unleſſe you come off thus.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: There is my Cloſet Key, doe what you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Engin.
sp.p: Gentlemen, Ile lead you to it, follow me.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: D'you uſe to find ſuch ſums as theſe beneath
An Oke, after a long March; I thinke ſure,
The wars are not ſo plentifull.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Wee thinke ſo too.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Y'had better traile a Bodkin, Gentlemen,
Under the Lady Ample, than a Pike
Under a German Generall.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Wee'l in for th'Mony Sir, and talk anon. Ex. Eng. Per. Meag.

div.stage: Enter Eld: Pallatine, Yo: Pallatine, Ample, Luce.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: Sir Tirant Thrift, here is your Ward come from
The dead, t'indite you for a Robbery
Upon her Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Hah! Is ſhee alive too?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Yes, and her Wardſhip out, before y'have profer'd her
A Husband Sir; ſo the beſt benefit
Of all your Guardianſhip is loſt.

sp.speaker: Ampl.
sp.l: In ſeven long yeares you could not Sir provide
A man deform'd enough, to offer mee
For your owne ends.

sp.speaker: Thrift.
sp.p: Couzen'd of wealth, of fame! Dog Engine! Ex. Thrift.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: Wee muſt have you enclos'd agen: y'are very
Forward with the Lady.

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.l: I will be Sir,
Vntill ſhee groane! this Prieſt ſtayes ſome what long.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: How's this? troth I ſhall forgive thee then heartily.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I've t'ane him i'th behalfe of health; to chide
And jeere, for recreation ſake, 'twill keepe
Mee Sir, in breath, now I am paſt growing.

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.l: Hearke Knight! here's relliſh for your eares. I choſe
None of your dull Country Madams, that ſpend
Their time in ſtudying Receipts, to make
March-Pane, and preſerve Plums; that talke
Of painfull Child-births, Servants wages, and
Their husbands good Complexion, and his Leg!

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.p: New wonders yet!

sp.speaker: El: Pall.
sp.l: What was that (Miſtris) which I ſeal'd to, hood-wink'd?
A ſimple triall of my confidence and love.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Your Brother has it, tis a gift to him
Of one faire Mannor, 'mongſt thoſe many that you
Have in Poſſeſſion Sir; and in this Bond,
Y'are witneſſe to three thouſand pounds I give to Luce!

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Yes Sir, for Pall and I muſt marry too.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.p: I were an Ev'nuch elſe, and th'world ſhould know't.

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.l: Thou couldſt not have betrayd mee to a bounty
I more love. Brother! Give thee joy!— Thw. takes Yo: Pall. aſide.

sp.speaker: Thw.
sp.l: You are the cauſe of all theſe Miracles:
Therefore I deſire you to be my heire;
By this good day you muſt: for I've t'ane order,
Though I love your Wit, you ſhall not live by it.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.p: My kind thanks Sir, the poore Mans gratitude.

sp.speaker: Miſt: Snor.
sp.l: 'Give you joy ſweet Maſter Pallatine, and
Your Brother too.

sp.speaker: Quea.
sp.l: And ſend you more ſuch wives,
Ev'ry yeare as many as ſhall pleaſe heaven.

sp.speaker: Snor.
sp.l: Tis day. Ile not to bed Sir now; my watch
Shall be drunke, at your worſhips wedding.

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: They ſhall, and there is Gold enough to keepe
Them ſo, untill thy reigne be out.—

div.stage: Enter Pert, Meager, Engine, with Money Bags.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Loaden with compoſition Pall.—

sp.speaker: Meag.
sp.p: Tis for your ſake wee grone under theſe burdens. —

sp.speaker: Yo: Pall.
sp.l: The Offall of Sir Tirants Trunks! Brother,
Pray know theſe Gentlemen, they owe you more
Money than they meane to pay now.

sp.speaker: Eld: Pal.
sp.l: I remember 'um: But no words my Cavalliers,
And you are ſafe. Where ſhall we dine to day?

sp.speaker: Yo: Pal.
sp.l: At Lucy's Aunts; wee'l make her coſtive Beldamſhip
Come off; when ſhee beholds a goodly joynture,
And our faire hopes.

sp.speaker: Eld: Pall.
sp.l: Firſt, to the Church. Lady,
Ile make your skittiſh perſon ſure. Some of
Your pleaſant Arts upon mee, may become
A wiſe Example, and a Morall too;
Such as their haughty fancie well befits,
That undertake to live here by their Wits. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: EPILOGVE.
div.l: THe office of an Epilogue, is now
To ſmooth &▪ ſtroke the wrinckles frō each brow;
To guide ſeverer judgements (if wee could
Be wiſe enough) untill they thought all good,
Which they perhaps diſlike; And ſure, this were
An over-boldneſſe, rais'd from too much Feare.
You have a Freedome, which wee hope you'l uſe,
T' advance our youthfull Poet, and his Muſe
With a kind Doome; And hee'l tread boldly then
In's best new Comick Socks, this Stage agen.
